responses.topic: Revenue, Operating Income, and Free Cash Flow
responses.content: Thanks, Dave. Today, we're reporting $143.3 billion in revenue, up 13% year-over-year, excluding the impact from foreign exchange rates; $15.3 billion in operating income, up 221% year-over-year or $10.5 billion; and $48.8 billion in trailing 12-month free cash flow adjusted for equipment finance leases, up $53.2 billion year-over-year. We remain focused on driving better experiences for our customers while also delivering efficiency improvements. Our financial results are an encouraging reminder of the progress we're making.

Starting with our stores business, despite having hundreds of millions of items and the broadest selection available, we remain intensely focused on adding even more selection. One way is to continue adding brands we know our customers want. For instance, in the U.S., we recently welcomed Clinique and two Gen Z fashion favorites, Parade and Cider, and announced a collaboration with Hardly Ever Worn It in Europe to offer customers pre-owned items from luxury brands.

Another way to drive selection is to make it easier for our third-party sellers to add their products to our store. We've recently launched a new generative AI tool that enables sellers to simply provide a URL to their own website, and we automatically create high-quality product detail pages on Amazon. Already, over 100,000 of our selling partners have used one or more of our gen AI tools.

Customers are shopping but remain cautious, trading down on price when they can and seeking out deals. In Q1, we helped customers save with shopping events worldwide, including our first big spring sale in Canada and the U.S. We also held spring deal days in Europe and our Ramadan event in Egypt, Saudi Arabia, and the UAE.

Delivery speed really matters to customers, and we've continued to get faster while improving our safety performance. In this past Q1, we delivered to Prime members at our fastest speeds ever. In March, across our top 60 largest U.S. metro areas, nearly 60% of Prime members' orders arrived the same or next day. And globally, in cities like Toronto, London, and Tokyo, about 3 out of 4 items were delivered the same or next day.

As we get items to customers this fast, customers choose Amazon to fulfill their shopping needs more frequently, and we can see the results in various areas, including how fast our Everyday Essentials business is growing and the continued increase in Prime member purchase frequency and total spend with us. We've continued to inspect our fulfillment network for additional opportunities and are working on several areas where we believe we can lower costs even further while also improving customer experience.

Advertising performance remained strong, with ad sales up 24% year-over-year, excluding the impact of foreign exchange. The strength in advertising was primarily driven by sponsored products, supported by continued improvements in relevancy and measurement capabilities for advertisers. We still see significant opportunity ahead in our sponsored products as well as areas where we're just getting started like Prime Video ads.

Moving to AWS. Year-over-year revenue growth accelerated to 17.2% in Q1, up from 13.2% in Q4. We see more absolute dollar growth quarter-over-quarter in AWS than we can see elsewhere. We're seeing significant momentum on the AI front with a multibillion-dollar revenue run rate already. We launched Trainium2 and continued to expand Bedrock with new capabilities and models from various providers. Our application layer includes Amazon Q, an expert coding companion, and Rufus, an expert shopping assistant.
Project Kuiper is getting closer to having its production satellites in space and entering our commercial beta.

Prime Video continues to produce compelling content, with 'Fallout' being our latest big hit on the heels of a very successful 'Road House' movie, with strong customer engagement in our original and partner content.

Our health services business is growing robustly as customers are loving our pharmacy customer experience, and we've launched same-day delivery of prescription medications to customers in 8 cities, including Los Angeles and New York City, with plans to expand to more than a dozen cities by the end of the year, with customers now getting first fill medications 75% faster year-over-year nationwide.

We expect the combination of AWS' reaccelerating growth and high demand for gen AI to meaningfully increase year-over-year capital expenditures in 2024, which is a positive sign of future growth. We remain enthusiastic about the opportunities ahead in every one of our businesses to make our customers' lives better and easier.

Worldwide revenue was $143.3 billion, representing a 13% year-over-year increase, excluding the impact of foreign exchange and near the top end of our guidance range. Operating income reached $15.3 billion for the quarter, an increase of $10.5 billion year-over-year and $2.2 billion above the high end of our guidance range.

responses.topic: Impact of Foreign Exchange and Leap Year
responses.content: We saw an unfavorable impact from global currencies weakening against the U.S. dollar, more than we had planned in Q1, leading to a $700 million or 50 basis point headwind to revenue relative to our guidance. Excluding this FX headwind, we would have exceeded the top end of our guidance range.

In the North America segment, first quarter revenue was $86.3 billion, an increase of 12% year-over-year. In the international segment, revenue was $31.9 billion, an increase of 11% year-over-year, excluding the impact of foreign exchange.

Third-party seller services revenue increased 16% year-over-year, excluding the impact of foreign exchange. We saw strong 3P unit growth, coupled with increased adoption of our optional services, such as fulfillment and global logistics. For the quarter, third-party seller unit mix was 61%, up 200 basis points year-over-year.

North America segment operating income was $5 billion, an increase of $4.1 billion year-over-year. Operating margin was 5.8%, up 460 basis points year-over-year. Improvements in our cost to serve, regionalization efforts, savings from more consolidated customer shipments, and improved leverage driven by strong unit growth and lower transportation rates contributed to this.

In our international segment, operating income was $902 million, an improvement of $2.2 billion year-over-year. Operating margin was 2.8%, up 710 basis points year-over-year, driven by cost efficiencies through network design enhancements and improved volume leverage in established countries, as well as progress in emerging countries.

AWS revenue was $25 billion, an increase of 17% year-over-year, bringing AWS to a $100 billion annualized revenue run rate. Excluding the impact from leap year, AWS revenue increased approximately 16% year-over-year. AWS operating income was $9.4 billion, an increase of $4.3 billion year-over-year.

In 2023, overall capital investments were $48.4 billion. We anticipate our overall capital expenditures to meaningfully increase year-over-year in 2024, primarily driven by higher infrastructure CapEx to support growth in AWS, including generative AI.

responses.topic: Q2 Revenue and Operating Income Guidance
responses.content: For Q2, net sales are expected to be between $144 billion and $149 billion, growing between 7% and 11% compared with Q2 2023. We expect an unfavorable foreign exchange impact of approximately 60 basis points. Operating income is expected to be between $10 billion and $14 billion in Q2.

We see several opportunities to further lower cost to serve and improve profitability in our worldwide stores business while still investing to improve the customer experience. Within our fulfillment network, we are focused on investing in our inbound network, streamlining and standardizing process paths, and adding robotics and automation.

questions: Historically, Amazon has shifted between periods of heavy investment and then margin expansion back into heavier investment, but you now have a much bigger base of gross profit and overall operating income. As you think about gen AI and capital intensity or grocery or Kuiper or health care, is there anything from an investment perspective that could materially impact profitability going forward in your view?

topics: AWS CapEx Intensity and Generative AI
questions: The CEO of Anthropic has said that the next generation of models costs around $1 billion to train, and the generation after that might be as much as $10 billion. Is this something that the industry will do on top of AWS, or does Amazon need to maintain state-of-the-art capabilities in-house? Additionally, how much did all this training impact the acceleration you saw in Q1 for AWS revenue?

topics: Cost to Serve and Capital Returns
questions: Can you quantify how to think about some of your North Star cost to serve goals over the next couple of years and what that could mean for potential accompanying reasonable ranges of outcomes for North America retail margins?
If cost to serve does improve, how do you think through the philosophy of returning capital to shareholders in addition to continuing to invest for the long run?

In September, you launched Amazon Supply Chain. Can you help us understand the opportunity you see there, where you are in that journey to build logistics as a service on a global basis, and does that require a step function increase in CapEx?

topics: Grocery Growth Drivers and Prime Video Advertising
questions: Regarding grocery, how much are changes to the threshold for free delivery or subscription prices contributing to your gross, and do you think you're over the hump or optimistic about it being a big category for you?
On Prime Video ramp, how did that ramp go versus your expectations, and do you think it could be a meaningful contributor to ad revenues going forward?

Can you talk about where you are in terms of international profitability, following a similar trajectory as North America with regionalization shifts and improvements in fulfillment architecture? Specifically, how might inbound fulfillment architecture add to continued benefits on faster shipping like same-day or next-day delivery?
